entry.title: New: Value Analytics for SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Upon the release of the Q2 2025 SAP Analytics Cloud Content and SAP Datasphere Content package, a new page has been added to the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story that is entirely dedicated towards SAP Fieldglass KPIs. This is the first of many updates to the tool that will expand its functionality far beyond SAP Ariba Procurement, allowing companies to analyze spend at a wider visibility than ever before.

The new page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement provides a big picture summary of SAP Fieldglass spend categories. Just like the other stories, users are presented with a clean and simplified view of data from select KPIs. Companies that choose to operationalize this new page may easily gain insights on their SAP Fieldglass data, including:

  • The influence of workforce management efficiency on overall revenue
  • Costs incurred by ensuring projects & hiring processes stay compliant
  • The financial impact of maintaining a quality workforce

If providing users with a way to further operationalize SAP Fieldglass data in a comprehensive analysis of spend piques your interest, please continue reading for more information on how to activate the new SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement.

1. SAP Analytics Cloud - Strategic Spend Overview

After opening the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story in SAP Analytics Cloud, navigate to the page entitled “Fieldglass”. Along with the title, the top module contains a summary of spend related to high-value KPIs in SAP Fieldglass. A dimension module with a "Date Range" filtering option appears below the title module, followed by three data visualization modules, entitled “Cost Savings”, “Compliance”, and “Process Improvement” to represent the major categories of Fieldglass Transactions.

SAP Fieldglass page view in SAP Analytics Cloud

2. SAP Datasphere Integration for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement

Initiating the activation of the SAP Fieldglass page requires some manual configuration. After the necessary reports are built in Fieldglass, the user must download them in CSV format and upload them into SAP Datasphere. All other relevant objects can be found in the SAP_CONTENT space.

As of Q2 2025, the images below are the most updated views of the integration architecture and the SAP Datasphere objects included in the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement package.

Integration architecture (updated to include SAP Fieldglass assets)

SAP Datasphere objects view (updated to Include SAP Fieldglass objects)

As a reminder, the following naming conventions have been used:
SM -> Supplier Management
SC -> Sourcing & Contracts
BI -> Buying & Invoicing
FG -> Fieldglass

The data modeling for the SAP Fieldglass page follows the layered approach of content development in SAP Datasphere. Here, the set up for SAP Fieldglass Project analysis is used as the example, the photo below describing the direction of the model layers:

SAP Fieldglass data model workflow

The Integration Layer (IL) contains the local table SAP Fieldglass: Project (LT) (SAP_Fieldglass_SRC_Project_MA), which was created in a manual file upload, as mentioned previously. In addition, this layer also includes the abstracting view, SAP Fieldglass: Project (IL) (SAP_PROC_FG_IL_Project), which adds data specific to the realm.

The Harmonization Layer (HL), SAP Fieldglass: Project (HL) (SAP_PROC_FG_HL_ProjectSQL), acts as the Fact View that combines Fieldglass project data with the Date Grid view.

Finally, the Reporting Layer (RL) uses the Analytic Model SAP Fieldglass: Project (RL) (SAP_PROC_FG_RL_Project) to define additional calculated measures and expose the data to the SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Analytics Cloud.

3. Content Documentation

Thank you for reading this SAP Community article!

To view the blog post on the original release of SAP Value Analytics for SAP Ariba Procurement in Q2 2024, please view ‘Maximize Value with Value Analytics for SAP Ariba’ by @SimonKranig.

For further instructions on configuring SAP Value Analytics for Procurement, please view this discovery mission.

More details on the SAP Fieldglass content package for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement can be found on this SAP Help page.

Have questions and want to share with other users? Feel free to post a question in the community:
SAP Community > SAP Analytics Cloud
SAP Community > SAP Datasphere

entry.title: Streamline SAC Custom Widget Development with Local Server
entry.content:
Developing custom widgets for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) enables developers to extend the platform’s built-in visualizations. But the development workflow can be repetitive. The cycle of editing code, bundling files, and uploading them to SAC for every small change slows down development.

This blog post introduces a streamlined workflow using a local Express.js server to serve your custom widget files directly from your development machine. This eliminates the need for repeated uploads and allows changes to be reflected immediately in SAC with a simple browser refresh.

Prerequisites

  • Node.js and npm: Make sure you have Node.js installed, which includes the npm package manager.

  • A Code Editor: Any modern editor like VS Code will work perfectly.

  • Your Custom Widget Project: You should have your widget's files (.js,.json, etc.) in a project folder (you can get this by cloning this github repo)

Use the Sample Widget Repository to Get Started Quickly

To help you get started, a ready-to-use GitHub repository is available. It contains:

  • A complete sample custom widget project

  • A package.json file for managing npm dependencies

  • A server.js file to launch a local Express.js server

  • A manifest file (podiumWidget.json) to upload to SAP Analytics Cloud

Steps to Run the Sample

Clone the Repository

git clone https://github.com/lkannan/analytics-cloud-creating-custom-widgets-learning-journey.git
cd analytics-cloud-creating-custom-widgets-learning-journey

Install Dependencies

npm install

Start the Local Server

npm start

This will launch the development server at: http://localhost:3000

Load the Widget in SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Navigate to the Stories > Custom Widget in SAC.

  • Upload the podiumWidget.json manifest file.

  • You do not need to upload a ZIP file, as the widget's JavaScript resources will be served from your local machine. ￼

  • Add the widget to a story and configure it as required. Which is to select a model in the builder panel of the custom widget and choose one dimension and one measure. The podium will show the top three measure values by the selected dimension. ￼

     

How the Local Server Works

The Express.js server is configured to serve static files from your project directory and includes headers to enable cross-origin resource sharing (CORS), which is required by SAC to fetch files from your local environment.

Below are the contents of server.js:

const express = require('express');
const app = express();
const port = 3000;

app.use((req, res, next) => {
  res.header('Access-Control-Allow-Origin', '*'); 
  res.header('Access-Control-Allow-Headers', 'Origin, X-Requested-With, Content-Type, Accept');
  next();
});

app.use(express.static('./'));

app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Development server running at http://localhost:${port}`);
});

Key Components

  • CORS Configuration: Required for SAC to access widget files hosted on your local machine.

  • Static File Serving: Ensures that JavaScript and related files are accessible directly via browser requests.

Example: Making a change and instantly seeing it in SAC

One of the key advantages of using a local development server is the ability to iterate quickly without packaging and uploading the widget repeatedly. Let’s walk through a simple customization adding a new font color, “SAP Blue,” to the widget’s styling options to see the benefits in action.

Before the Change: Existing Font Color Options in SAC

Initially, the drop-down menu in the widget's story configuration panel showed a limited set of font colors (e.g., Black, Red, Green, etc.). These were defined in the style-panel.js file of the widget.

Making the Change: Editing the Styling Configuration

To add “SAP Blue” as an additional color option, we simply edit the HTML <select> element in style-panel.js by adding a new <option>:

<option value="#0A6ED1">SAP Blue</option>

After the Change: Updated Widget in SAC with New Color Option

After refreshing the SAC story in the browser, the newly added "SAP Blue" option becomes instantly available in the font color dropdown. No need to repackage or re-upload the widget ZIP file.

This simple enhancement clearly illustrates how a local server setup speeds up custom widget development, testing, and debugging. It empowers developers to experiment freely and see results in real time boosting both productivity and creativity.

Benefits of the Local Development Approach

  • Faster Development Cycle: Skip the need to zip and upload files for each change.

  • Immediate Feedback: Refresh the story in SAC to test the latest code instantly.

  • Better Debugging: Use browser developer tools and console logging without deployment delays.

  • Simplified Collaboration: Work locally and integrate with version control systems easily.

Considerations

  • Localhost is for development only: This setup is intended solely for local development and testing. Once your widget is fully developed and tested, you should host the resource files in a production-ready environment such as SAP Analytics Cloud itself, GitHub, or any secure web server. Update the file paths in your widget’s JSON descriptor to point to the hosted URLs before deploying to production.

  • Network accessibility: Ensure that SAC can reach your local machine. You may need to use your machine's IP address if localhost is blocked or inaccessible.

  • Port conflicts: If port 3000 is already in use, update the port in both server.js and the widget manifest file.

Related Resources:

  • Custom Widget Detailed Blog
  • SAP Analytics Cloud Custom Widget Samples

entry.title: The New Table Building Experience in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
With the 2025 Q3 QRC release of SAP Analytics Cloud, we’re excited to introduce the brand-new Table Builder Panel, aligning the table design process closer with that of Charts and Geo Visualizations to streamline story creation.

Within this Blog Post, we will highlight the key analytics enhancements. These are broken down as the following sections:

  1. Ghost Table
  2. New Builder Panel
  3. Functional Enhancements

For planning-related updates with the new Table Builder Panel, see Improved Input Readiness and Unbooked Data Display in SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Ghost Table

A Ghost Table now appears when a new table is added or enters an error state. For initial creation, it prevents an unnecessary query from being processed and lets designers select the desired object, ensuring a consistent and guided experience. We’ve also introduced better error handling in the case of cyclic dependencies, missing entities, and so on.

For SAP BW queries, the table automatically inherits the layout, filters, and settings from the underlying query.

 

New Builder Panel

We’ve introduced a new Builder Panel that aligns the table-building experience with that of Charts and Geo Visualizations. There are several enhancements which include:

  1. Available Object Panel
  2. Flexible Totals and Parent Node Positioning
  3. Improved Drop-Down List for Object Selection
  4. New Member Selector
  5. Table Add-Ons
  6. Single Source for Table Styling

Available Objects Panel

The new Table Builder Panel introduces the option to open the Available Object List, giving visibility into the full structure and objects of the data model. There are a few benefits which include:

  • A smoother, uninterrupted design experience with access to the complete object list
  • Easy addition of objects via drag-and-drop or the more actions icon (i.e. Add to Column or Add to Rows)
  • Clear identification of dimension types through intuitive icons in the object list

 

Flexible Totals and Parent Nodes Positioning

We've transitioned from a centralized "Show Totals and Parent Position" setting to independent controls for the Rows and Columns axes giving Designers greater flexibility to tailor the table layout to their needs.

 

Improved Drop-Down Menu for Object Selection

We've enhanced the selection process for Primary and Secondary Structure Members. Instead of using the Member Selector, users can now select individual members directly from a drop-down menu. The menu has been expanded to span the full width of the Builder Panel, making it easier to locate and select the desired member.

ℹ️Designers can continue to use the Member Selector for more advanced selections for Primary and Secondary Structures.

 

Integration of the New Member Selector

Designers now benefit from the New Member Selector when creating local filters or selecting Primary and Secondary Structures. For Primary and Secondary Structures, a multi-tab layout appears when input controls are detected, simplifying element selection.

Furthermore, support for Primary Structure Filters (Accounts or Measures) has been extended to non-SAP BW models, broadening their applicability.

 

Table Add-Ons

We've improved the discoverability of table add-ons such as In-Cell Chart, Linked Analysis, Hyperlink, and Threshold by introducing a dedicated Add-On section, a consistent experience with Chart and Geographical Visualizations.

A dedicated In-Cell Chart Panel has been introduced, allowing users to configure all In-Cell Chart settings in one place. Options like Show Data Value and Axis Line Color have been moved from the Styling Panel to this new, centralized panel for easier access and a more streamlined design experience.

 

Single Source for Styling

Adaptive Column Width has moved from the Builder Panel, and the Display of Units/Currencies has moved from the Number Formatting to a central location in the Styling Panel under Table Properties.

 

Functional Enhancements

With the new Builder Panel, we’ve introduced several functional enhancements to improve the creation and customization of tabular visualizations. There are several enhancements which include:

  1. Ranking & Sorting Improvements
  2. Report to Report Interface Enhancements
  3. Blended Table Improvements
  4. Flexibility with the Version Dimension
  5. Show / Hide Threshold Tooltip Details
  6. Hierarchal and Multi-Selection Primary Structure Input Control
  7. New Client Calculations Panel

Ranking and Sorting

We’ve introduced several enhancements to Sort and Rank in Tables, giving users greater flexibility and control.

Sorts in Table are no longer version dependent. When dimensions are placed on both axes, you can now choose to apply sorting to either rows or columns and specify the dimension members to sort. Additionally, Keep Left Columns Group has been renamed to Break Grouping for consistency with chart terminology.

For ranking, Create Top N is now simply Rank to align terminology with charts, with extended capabilities including support for:

  • Ranking across Multiple Dimensions
  • Ranking SAP BW characteristics with collapsed hierarchies

 

Report-Report Interface Enhancements

For SAP BW live connections, the 'Jump To' menu now supports additional targets like Web Dynpro, ABAP reports, and custom BAdIs.

You can also navigate from a wider range of cell types including headers and total cells.

 

Blended Tables

Blended Tables are now supported in the new Builder Panel, with several key improvements:

  • Sort and Rank functionality are now available
  • Description Format (Short, Medium, and Long Text) is supported for SAP BW data
  • Apply Conditions can be used with SAP BW models

⚠️Migration of Blended Tables from Classic Experience is not supported and we now require at least one linked dimension within the Table.

 

Flexibility with the Version Dimension

There is now an option to delete the default version filter that is applied to a Table without forcing a single value filter. It provides Planners the flexibility to have the visualization dynamically update to reflect a specific or multiple versions.

It is up to the Story Designer to ensure that the Tables meets at least one of these conditions to display data:

  • The version dimension is added to the Table (i.e. on Rows or Axis)
  • Ensure there is a single value filter on version (via a Local Filter, Story Filter, Page, Filter, or Linked Analysis)
  • Consume a restricted Primary Structure (Account or Measure) or Secondary Structure on version

 

Show / Hide Threshold Tooltip Details

For Thresholds that are shown within the Table, we now provide the flexibility to show the Threshold Tooltip Details. It hides information such as the Threshold, Threshold Name, the Range, and the Bullet Chart.

 

Hierarchal and Multi-Selection Primary Structure Input Control

We’ve expanded the Primary Structure Input Control to support additional selection types: Multiple Selection, Single Selection Hierarchy, and Multiple Selection Hierarchy. It uses the New Member Selector for a consistent experience.

Tables now support consumption of both Multiple Selection and Multiple Selection Hierarchy input controls, in addition to Single Selection and Single Selection Hierarchy, giving Designers greater flexibility to build dynamic, user-driven tables.

For existing input controls, the current configuration will remain unchanged. However, once edited and confirmed, they will automatically update to the new input control format.

⚠️ Charts and Geo visualizations do not support Multiple Selection or Multiple Selection Hierarchy and will return an error if used.

 

New Client Calculations Panel

We've introduced a client-side Calculation Panel to help Designers easily manage calculations used within the Table. Designers can quickly format, edit, or delete a calculation by selecting the corresponding action from the panel.

This release is only the beginning. You can expect ongoing improvements that will make tables more dynamic, interactive, and customizable, pushing the boundaries of what’s possible within SAP Analytics Cloud. As always, your feedback continues to shape our roadmap, and we’re excited to evolve together as we reimagine how tables can drive decisions and insights across the enterprise.

Stay tuned, there’s much more to come!

 

SAP Analytics Cloud Documentation on New Table Building Experience

For the full list of current restrictions with the New Table builder, please reference our official documentation.

entry.title: Improved Input Readiness and Unbooked Data Display in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Challenges with Traditional Unbooked Planning Tables

In current planning tables using unbooked mode, all combinations of dimension members are shown even if some combinations are not plannable:

  • The combination being invalid due to validation rules
  • The user lacking write access to the members
  • The combination being locked by data locking

And the non-writeable cells due to data security aren’t shown as read-only.

As a result, planners often face large and complex tables with full member combinations. This increases the chance of mistakenly entering data into non-plannable cells, leading to errors or incorrect disaggregation, and creating confusion, wasted effort and planning inaccuracies.

 

The Improved Input Readiness and Unbooked Data Display

With the QRC3 2025 release in SAP Analytics Cloud, there are a few significant improvements to input readiness and the display of unbooked data, making planning more intuitive and efficient.

  • Planners gain clear guidance on where they can plan data
  • Story designers benefit from simplified configurations.

Note:  these new capabilities require opting in to the new table build experience.  See this blog for more details about the new table build experience.

 

Key Capabilities

Visualized Locking for Input Readiness: Cells that are locked by data access control automatically appear as input-disabled. Planners no long guess where to enter data. The optional “Reasons for Unplannable Data” helps explain the cell is input-disabled because the user is lacking write access.

Safe and Secure Data Disaggregation: when your model has data access control, values entered at a parent node are disaggregated only to leaf nodes where planning is allowed.

Note: Input Readiness and Disaggregation now fully support:

  • Validation rule
  • Data locking
  • Data access control (new in the QRC3 2025 release)

Cleaner Views with Hiding of Unplannable Unbooked Rows/Columns: Rows and columns where all cells are unbooked and input-disabled (due to validation rule or data access control) are automatically hidden. It gives planners a cleaner and more focused view.  

Note: in the QRC3 2025 release, the unbooked rows/columns locked only by data locking are not hidden.

Unified and Simplified Planning Security Settings:  In the table design panel:

  • Data disaggregation and input enablement settings are now managed with a single toggle, making configuration faster and less error prone.   
  • Story designers can enforce or ignore individual planning security types: data access control, validation rule and data locking - enabling full flexibility to design different scenarios or simulate planning.

 

Explore With Examples

Assume your model has:

  1. Data access control: You can write to “Canada” and “Mexico”, but “USA” is read-only.
  2. Validation rule: Product “P1” is valid for “Canada”, and Product “P2” is valid for “USA” and “Mexico”

Combination

Plannable?

 

P1 + Canada

✅Yes

Valid combination and write access

P1 + Mexico

❌No

Invalid combination and write access

P1 + USA

❌No

Invalid combination and no write access

P2 + Canada

❌No

Invalid combination and write access

P2 + USA

❌No

Valid combination but no write access

P2 + Mexico

✅Yes

Valid combination and write access

 

Prerequisite: your story uses the new table build experience, which you can enable by clicking “Switch All Tables to New Build Experience” to opt in.

Input Readiness Enhancements based on Data Access Control and Validation Rule

With the QRC3 2025 release, input readiness now respects data access control, in addition to validation rule and data locking.

The cell (P1 + USA) is shown as unplannable, with both reasons explained.

The cell (“P1”, “Canada”) is plannable and input-ready.

You no longer need to add every dimension involved in validation rules to the table. If a dimension used in validation rule is not in the table nor filters, it’s treated as if all members are selected.

Any filter applied to a dimension involved in validation rule or data access control is automatically taken in account when determining input readiness, which boosts the accuracy of input readiness. For example,

  • When all 3 regions are selected in the filter, its parent “North America” stays input-enabled because it has at least an eligible child “Canada”.

  • When only “USA” (without write access) is selected in the filter, “North America” becomes input-disabled because all its children in the table are now input-disabled.

 

Data Disaggregation based on Data Access Control

In the model preference, a new toggle - “Disaggregated on Data Access Control” - is available.  

  • Turned on by default for newly created models.
  • Turned off by default for existing models to preserve current behavior. 
  • You can turn it on or off manually, depending on your needs.

When this toggle is turned on, values entered at a parent node are disaggregated only to leaf nodes with write access. In the example above, write access is granted to “Canada” and “Mexico” but “P1 + Mexico” is invalid due to validation rule. Therefore, the data is disaggregation to “P1 + Canada” where write access is permitted and the combination is valid.

 

Auto-Hiding of Unplannable Unbooked Rows/Columns

In the table design panel, a new table configuration – “Hide Unplannable Unbooked Data” – is available.

When this configuration option is turned on,

  • Entire rows or columns containing only unbooked and input-disabled cells (due to validation rule or data access control) are automatically hidden.
  • This creates a cleaner and more focused table, allowing users to focus on plannable cells.

In the example above, only “P1 + Canada” and “P2 + Mexico” cells are plannable due to validation rule and data access control. Other rows that are unplannable and unbooked are hidden. 

Note: in the QRC3 2025 release, the unbooked rows/columns locked only by data locking are not hidden.

The input -disabled but booked cells remain visible in the table as they contribute to the parent level aggregation.  In this example, you have read access to “USA”, so the “USA” row is displayed but locked. Other rows that are unplannable and unbooked are hidden.

 

 

Simplified and Harmonized Table Settings for Planning Security

In the table design panel, story designers can now decide whether to enable or ignore planning security.

  • When enabled:
    • Cells that are locked by data locking, validation rule or data access control appear as readonly. 
    • Data disaggregation respects model disaggregation settings.
  • When disabled:
    • Cells are input-enabled and values are disaggregated to all leaf nodes.

 

Conclusion

With these new capabilities, planners are empowered to work more confidently and efficiently, while ensuring consistency and accuracy.

  • Improved input readiness
  • Data disaggregation respecting data access control, validation rule and data locking
  • Cleaner and focused table views, automatically hiding all unplannable unbooked rows and columns
  • Simplified configuration for story designers

entry.title: Driving Variance Colors in SAC Based on Calculated Measures in Numeric Point Charts Using Thresholds
entry.content:
Driving Custom Variance Colors in SAP SAC Based on Calculated Measures in Numeric Point Charts

SAP Analytics Cloud's chart variance functionality enables users to visualize differences between measure versions or temporal data points, supporting calculations between any two measures regardless of their inclusion in the primary visualization. Organizations can configure these variances to incorporate version-based, time-based, or standalone comparisons according to their analytical requirements.

The platform's dynamic variance capabilities provide contextual responsiveness, automatically recalculating variance metrics when underlying measures within the visualization are modified. This ensures that variance displays remain current and accurate as users navigate through different analytical perspectives, enhancing the overall analytical workflow and decision-making process.

In this post, we'll review how to drive Custom Variance Colors in SAP SAC based on Calculated Measures in numeric point charts, enabling clearer comparisons between two versions at any point in time. This approach enhances custom visualization aesthetics and improves data interpretation through strategic color coding aligned with business thresholds and performance indicators.

1. Insert a Chart and Choose Visualization Type

Add a chart to your story and set its type to Numeric Point.

2. Select the Primary Account

Choose your desired account—this can be a parent or a leaf account.

3. Add Restricted Measures

Go to:
Add Measure → Add Calculation → Restricted Measure

Create two restricted measures based on version and date:

  • Actuals 2025

  • Budget 2025

4. Create Variance Measures

Define two calculated measures to compare values:

  • Actuals vs. Budget: Actuals 2025 - Budget 2025

  • Budget vs. Actuals: Budget 2025 - Actuals 2025

5. Set Up Thresholds

  • Add a Threshold

  • Create two rules by filtering on the calculated measures:

    • One where positive values are green and negative are red

    • One where positive values are red and negative are green

 

6. Enable Thresholds via Trellis

Clicking Show Threshold may not work immediately — the “Story Defined” option could be greyed out as shown below.

To fix this:

  • Go to the Chart Add-On panel

  • Add a Trellis, selecting measures

 

Once the Trellis is added, the threshold option becomes available.
Select your threshold, and you’ll now be able to drive variance colors based on the calculated measure filters set up in the background.

Conclusion:

By leveraging calculated measures and trellis-based thresholds, SAP SAC users can dynamically drive custom variance colors in numeric point charts. This empowers more intuitive and immediate visual insights into performance deviations. The result is a more engaging and effective analytical experience aligned with organizational KPIs.

entry.title: Chart Enhancements in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
With the 2025 Q3 QRC release of SAP Analytics Cloud, we’re excited to introduce a series of enhancements to our Charts that are designed to provide more flexibility and control in the Optimized Experience. These updates are aimed at improving the visual appeal and the analytical precision of your dashboards, helping you tell a clearer story with your data.

Within this Blog Post, we will highlight the key enhancements which include:

  1. New Design for Numeric Point Chart
  2. Grid Lines 
  3. Axis Titles
  4. Axis Line Thickness
  5. Grouped Category Divider Line Color and Thickness

You can find an example of how these improvements can visually enhance your existing dashboard

 

New Design for Numeric Point Chart

The Numeric Point Chart has been redesigned to better align with modern dashboard aesthetics and to improve readability. With the fresh look, we ensure key figures stand out more prominently, making it easier for users to quickly grasp performance metrics.

Given that the Numeric Point Chart is significantly different, we have decided that it must be enabled on a per Chart basis which is non-reversible. For new Charts, it is automatically made available.

 

Grid Lines

We’ve introduced Grid Lines which can be toggled on and off via the Designer in the Charts Show / Hide settings. It can help improve the readability of the Chart and make it easier to interpret data points that have their data labels hidden due to collision. There is an option to update the color of the Grid Lines via the Styling Panel.

 

Axis Titles

For Viewers to have better context, Designers can now add Axis Titles which reflects the name of the bound object. It helps in understanding what data is being represented on each axis.

For the Axis Title, we allow the configure of the color and position. For the X-Axis Title we support a left, center, and right alignment while for the Y-Axis we support a centre and top alignment.

 

Axis Line Thickness

The thickness of axis lines can now be adjusted between Thin, Medium, and Thick via the Styling Panel under Axis Line. It can be used to suit your design preferences or to emphasize specific aspects of a chart.

 

Grouped Category Divider Line Color and Thickness

Designers now can customize the color and thickness of divider lines between grouped dimensions. This improvement enhances the clarity of grouped data and helps in distinguishing between different segments more effectively.

 

Within the Blog Post, we also wanted to highlight a few improvements that were shipped in previous releases that could be beneficial. The key enhancements include:

  1. Adjust Bar Width at Widget Level
  2. Improved Data Label Position for "Line" based Charts
  3. Sort with 100% Stacked Bar Charts

 

Adjust Bar Width at Widget Level

You can now adjust the bar width at the widget level, instead of having to use Chart Scaling, giving designers greater control over the appearance of individual bar and column charts.

Setting the widget-level bar width overrides chart scaling bar width and default bar width settings for the chart. All other chart scaling settings are still applied.

 

Improved Data Label Position for “Line” based Charts

We’ve improved the positioning of data labels for line-based charts to enhance readability. Labels are now placed more intelligently based on the chart layout and available space.

 

 

Sort with 100% Stacked Bar Charts

We now support sorting for 100% stacked bar charts, allowing users to order categories based on values or measures. This enhancement improves data analysis by making trends and comparisons easier to interpret.

 

These enhancements are part of our continued effort to empower users with precise, customizable, and visually engaging tools in SAP Analytics Cloud. Stay tuned for more updates as we evolve the platform to meet your analytical needs.

entry.title: Announcing the SAP Analytics Cloud Home Page Redesign
entry.content:
At SAP, we're always looking for ways to make your experience better, more efficient, and more enjoyable. That’s why I'm thrilled to introduce our Redesigned SAP Analytics Cloud Home Page for the 2025 Q3 QRC release.

What is the New SAC Home Page?

The new SAC Home Page is designed to help you navigate and access key resources more seamlessly. With this updated interface, you can now enjoy a more intuitive layout, enhanced customization options, and improved performance for a smoother experience. 

Why You’ll Love It

Here are just a few reasons why the new SAC Home Page is a game-changer:

  • Enhanced Usability: Streamlined navigation makes it easier to find what you need, when you need it.

  • Personalized Experience: Customize your SAC Home page to prioritize the tools and insights most relevant to you.

  • Faster Performance: Optimized loading times ensure a more efficient workflow.

A total of five new cards are being introduced to the SAC home page. Let's take a closer look at them.

Onboarding Card

It provides a brand new onboarding experience. It includes links to helpful tutorials and learning courses, so you can get up to speed with the product in no time.

The card also comes with a search bar where you can type in questions you might have directly. It will lead you to our help documentation with the most fitting results for your query.

Quick Actions Card

It lets you select up to four quick actions from a broad selection, to add to your home page, for quick access to your most frequent daily tasks like creating a story or a model.

Just Ask Card

What's also new is that Just Ask now comes as a card with an advanced search bar. Powered by generative AI, it lets you initiate searches from the home page using natural language.

Not only does it let you enter your search, but it also lets you refine it by selecting your data and adding attributes. The Just Ask feature then opens and pre-populates your search from the card with results.

Resources Card

To help you explore our community, see upcoming updates, and learn more about SAC roadmap, we've created the Resources card.

This card provides quick and easy access to various types of information about the product. You can find everything from a sample custom widgets to business content, release updates, and more.

Favourites Card

The final card we'd like to introduce is the Favourites card. It displays files you've favourited and allows you to filter them.

You can find the filter settings in the card's submenu. The dialog lets you filter by all file types and you can choose to apply one or multiple filters for the card.

Besides all of our new cards, we've also improved and revamped some of our existing cards, which are : 

  • Calendar highlights
  • Recent files
  • Featured files
  • and Data Change Insights

The cards all come with search functions and improved filtering experiences and capabilities. So you can display and find the information you're looking for easily.

How to Customize it 

All of our cards are repositionable, and the card layout is responsive. If you decide to reposition a card, all the other cards will adjust accordingly. For further customization, you can open the home page settings dialog. It's still available via the user profile. However, for quicker access, we've added a "Customize" button to the top right area of the home page.

The home page settings dialog provides you with the option to select your default home page experience and show and hide functions for all the available cards.

What's next ?

Within the next releases we will introduce:

  • New cards
  • Enable the card Resizing 
  • Introducing cards dedicated to the SAC Administrator 
  • New user profile settings
  • New Theming features 

Stay tuned for more updates !

entry.title: 移动设备故事设计的最佳实践指南
entry.content:
介绍

借助SAP分析云，设计人员和开发人员在创建故事时可以使用大量灵活的功能。然而，考虑这些复杂的故事可能对​​移动设备​​中的用户体验和运行性能产生的影响是十分重要的。

​​在本篇博客中，我们将重点介绍一些最佳实践指南，供设计人员和开发人员在为移动设备创作故事时参考。

最佳实践

为了提供流畅且用户友好的体验，设计人员和开发人员可以参考一些最佳实践指南。这些指南可分为三部分：

  • 理解移动设备硬件规格
  • 故事简化（对象与高级特性）​
  • 移动设备上的测试与验证

理解移动设备硬件规格

设计人员和开发人员应该熟悉SAP分析云的移动硬件规格。这是因为根据整个业务中可用的设备，应遵循不同的最佳实践指南。以下是每个设备的一些推荐的最佳实践指南：

设备内存大小（iPad和iPhone）

最大页面数量（推荐）

iPad 单页单元权重总量（推荐）

iPhone 单页单元权重总量（推荐）

3GB

3

2.5

2.5

4GB

4

3.0

2.5

6GB

5

4.0

2.5

8GB

7

4.5

3.5

16GB 

10

5.0

N/A

故事简化（对象与高级特性）​

设计人员和开发人员应该了解在移动设备上向消费者展示哪些信息是重要的。因为与笔记本电脑不同，移动设备的屏幕尺寸和设备内存有限。

技巧1. 降低仪表盘整体复杂度​

从便利性角度出发，将所有信息整合至单一故事颇具吸引力。然而，此举可能导致​​信息过载​​，并​​使移动设备体验复杂化​​。因为页面数量与对象的组合会增加故事大小，进而导致运行处理时间的增加。

注意：当与设计数据相关的小部件数量和页面数量超过建议数量时，设计时会发出警告。

  • · 限制单页上数据相关小部件的数量：建议将这些内容分散到多个页面中。对于流式布局面板或响应式布局，可以使用响应规则配置来根据设备隐藏特定的小部件。
  • 限制故事页的数量：建议同时限制单个故事板内的页面总数。创建更精简的故事，并利用​​故事之间的超链接​​实现跨故事导航。

技巧2. 限制“高消耗”可视化对象的数量

鉴于移动设备内存普遍低于Web端，且不同移动设备内存容量差异显著，​​因此严格控制内存密集型微件的数量十分重要​​。各微件类型的单位权重值详情可参阅SAP帮助门户文档。

以下为高消耗微件示例：

  • ​​地理可视化对象​​
    • ​​表
    • ​​时间序列统计图​​
    • ​​自定义微件

注意：对于​​地理可视化对象，还有进一步的建议，即​​每页至多包含一个​​地理可视化对象​​，​​且在该可视化对象中限制图层数（不超过三个）。

注意：一个故事中筛选器的数量能会影响移动设备上的性能

技巧3. 限制复杂脚本的使用

使用优化体验，有许多可用的 API，允许开发者创建开箱即用的自定义应用或工作流，这意味着低效的脚本或复杂的脚本会对移动设备体验产生影响，原因在于其会增大处理负载并引发移动设备闪退。

在各种移动设备上进行测试和验证

​注意：以上提示均属最佳实践指南。鉴于移动设备硬件配置差异显著，必须逐台验证使用体验。

技巧1. 预览和测试

故事中的设备预览功能是验证多设备适配效果的实用工具，但若需确保界面响应灵敏、体验流畅易用，物理设备预览与测试环节依然至关重要。

技巧2. 性能和内存验证

作为技巧1的扩展，侧重点在于​​要求跨多种设备的（如3, 4, 6, 8+ GB内存），对故事进行充分测试​​。这能为用户​​规避内存溢出（OOM）问题提供额外保障​​。

结论

借助这些最佳实践指南，设计人员和开发人员将能够优化他们的故事以供移动设备使用，确保流畅且用户友好的体验

随着 SAP分析云的 2024 年第四季度(Q4)季度发布更新(QRC)​​，SAC移动设备iOS应用将对兼容的故事启用精简版查看器。该技术将​​显著降低在移动设备上打开故事时的运行内存消耗​​。

原文链接：Best Practice Guide for Designing Stories for Mobi... - SAP Community

原作者：Kapil, Tunir

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA configuration for SAC pull of plan data
entry.content:
This post deals with the SAP S/4HANA app “Manage Financial Plan Data Jobs - for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration” (in the following referred to as “manage” app) where mandatory configuration settings for pulling plan data from SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) into SAP S/4HANA tables like ACDOCP or FINSSKF are defined. These configuration settings are prerequisite for the app “Schedule Financial Plan Data Jobs for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration“ to execute a financial plan data job (for data replication). The integration using these two apps is available in SAP S/4HANA Public and Private Cloud Edition.

The goal is to provide guidance on the necessary configuration settings in this manage app and show example configurations based on SAC content for different use cases.

It is recommended to bookmark this post, as we plan to enhance it with further recommendations and configuration settings.

Before creating a configuration in this manage app, a tenant ID (with communication details) must be created first which is explained in the following online help:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/1cbcff7ccd35405ab445b223c1ab1588/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US
  • SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/48f4b4785b8e45938ac44a67be8032d9/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US

This post is based on the following SAC content for Integrated Financial Planning with possible plan data replications into S/4HANA tables but apply to other (customer specific) SAC models writing into these S/4HANA tables as well.

To simplify, we assume that depreciations are copied from the SAC model CAPEX to model OPEX and asset values ​​from the SAC model CAPEX to model Financial Statement Planning. So we only deal with configuration entries for plan data related to OPEX, Sales and Profitability Planning and Financial Statement. CO2 values ​​are also ignored (might be addressed in a later version of this post).

We start with functional and technical basics, continue with general recommendations and finally show some example configurations.

Functional Basics

For replication of plan data related to the three IFP models OPEX, Profitability and Financial Statement into SAP S/4HANA, the following SAC modeling details must be considered:

  • In contrast to Profitability and Financial Statement, only OPEX has a dimension for the debit/credit indicator to represent cost charges and discharges. However, for profitability and financial statement data, the debit/credit indicator ‘D’ is added by default when writing into table ACDOCP. The debit/credit indicator becomes part of the plan data scope explained below.
  • When transferring sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability, the same account used to post into Profitability is used to credit records in OPEX. However, in contrast to OPEX, product and plant information is added to these costs in Profitability.
  • The starting point for financial statement planning is a copy of actual data from the previous year’s financial statement. Then plan data from OPEX and Profitability are copied into Financial Statement, i.e. these copy processes do NOT result in corresponding credit records on the sender side.
  • The IFP content in SAC offers two possible sources for bringing a profit and loss statement into table ACDOCP:
    • Option 1: The model Financial Statement serves as the source to ensure a complete P&L statement. Since the copy of actual data is used as a starting point, the data can contain recurring extraordinary revenues and costs like the dissolution of accruals etc. 
    • Option 2: The two models OPEX and Profitability serve as the source. Here special attention is required for the account(s) used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability (more on this later). In contrast to Option 1, this option has only operating costs and revenues.

Technical Basics

It is important to understand that contrary to table ACDOCA, table ACDOCP represents a multidimensional view. Therefore, the key fields of table ACDOCP consist of purely technical fields. This makes it necessary to specify a so-called aggregation level and plan data scope when writing data into table ACDOCP. These are explained below (among other technical terms for the Manage app).

  1. Aggregation level
    The aggregation level determines the fields of the records for which plan data is transferred into SAP S/4HANA. In the following mapping view of the configuration for the SAC plan data pull, the listed SAP S/4HANA fields are automatically translated into this aggregation level:
    As you can see in the last four columns of the screenshot above, it does not matter for the derivation of the aggregation level whether the field is mapped 1:1 from SAC, derived from an attribute (of an SAC dimension), or defined as a fixed value.
  2. Plan Data Scope
    The plan data scope influences which existing data records in table ACDOCP are replaced by the new plan data. Therefore, based on the fields marked “In Scope” (i.e. plan data scope) and their corresponding values from the plan data (to be written into ACDOCP), a data set is identified in the (multidimensional) table ACDOCP.
    It is important to understand that for the derivation of this “data set” not only the existing value combinations from the fields marked as “In Scope” are used, but also cross-combinations of these field values (see example 3 below).
    The following three scenarios show how new plan data with the respective plan data scope setting overwrites existing data in table ACDOCP.
    The more fields are added to the plan data scope, the fewer existing records can be overwritten with the new data, and thus the impacted data section is smaller (see example 2). This is also the reason why some fields such as the planning category or time-related fields like LedgerFiscalYear or FiscalYearPeriod are mandatory in the plan data scope, so that more data than desired is not accidentally overwritten when writing plan data into ACDOCP.
    In the configuration of the manage application, the plan data scope is defined in following highlighted column of the mapping view.
  3. Interaction between update mode and plan data scope
    Because the update mode for reading the relevant plan data records in SAC is a full update, SAC data is always written as a “whole” into table ACDOCP. Therefore, for cost-center-related costs, for example, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope (to replace the existing cost-center-related accounts and periods with the new plan data). Another example are project-related costs, where the WBSElement, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope. This ensures that the new plan data from SAC replaces the existing data in ACDOCP correctly.
  4. Account selection
    In the Filter Settings section of a configuration ID in the Manage app, meaningful data selections via G/L accounts are limited, as hierarchy nodes are not supported for the account field. For example, selecting primary accounts, cost accounts or balance sheet accounts using hierarchy nodes is not supported. Unfortunately, this type of selection is only possible via flat account selection, where the relevant accounts are then listed.
  5. Lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP
    Given that the lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP is based on the SAP S/4HANA fields PlanningCategory, ControllingArea, CompanyCode and LedgerFiscalYear, simultaneously running pull jobs into the same planning category can lock each other (for overlapping controlling areas, company code and fiscal year). However, in SAP S/4HANA no locks can occur if simultaneous pull jobs are writing into different planning categories. Therefore this should be considered when using multiple configuration IDs.

General configuration-specific recommendations

After clarifying some functional and technical basics, let’s look at the following recommendations for the configuration:

  • In general, overlapping plan data across different configurations which are written into the same planning category inevitably leads to inconsistent data when running the financial plan data jobs for the respective configuration IDs (due to the conflict with the plan data scope and subsequent mutual overwriting). An example of this is the configuration for (total) expenses and another configuration specifically for project-related expenses (subset of total expenses). Therefore, it is important to avoid such cases by defining different plan categories in the mapping section for the SAP S/4HANA field PlanningCategory.
  • Plan data from the IFP model Financial Statement must always kept in a separate planning category (in contrast to plan data from the IFP models OPEX and Sales & Profitability) to avoid inconsistencies due to duplicate figures. The reason is that OPEX und Sales & Profitability data is copied into the SAC model Financial Statement without crediting on the sender side.
  • In the case of writing OPEX and Profitability data into one planning category (for an alternative P&L report in SAP S/4HANA), having the field GLAccount as an additional “In Scope” field helps differentiate the two data sets (to avoid mutual overwrite), if OPEX and Sales & Profitability use different GL accounts. However, if, for example, a single GL account is used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Sales and Profitability, this approach no longer ensures disjoint data, and the plan data scope must be expanded. If, as shown in the following example, OPEX consists only of cost center data (and is marked as “In Scope”), and all Sales & Profitability data has a Plant, Sold Material and Customer allocation (and is marked as “In Scope”), disjoint data is ensured as well (without mutual overwrite):
  • A mapping of profit center and functional area values for a given configuration ID in the view ”Mapping of Financial Plan Data” ​​(to transfer both fields from SAC) is optional for OPEX and Profitability, since both would be automatically derived in the ACDOCP write interface if missing. If, however, Profit Center and Functional Area are mapped (and thus transferred from SAC), the correct profit center and functional area assignment is checked in SAP S/4HANA before writing plan data into table ACDOCP.  If this consistency check fails because, for example, the derived account assignment type returns a different profit center, an error message appears and the data transfer is aborted. Therefore, when mapping the functional area and/or profit center, ensure that the master data in SAP Analytics Cloud is up to date.
  • When using the SAP-delivered planning categories BUDGET01, BUDGET02 and BUDGET03 when writing into table ACDOCP,  the following default value for Budget Consistency Check (screenshot taken from SSCUI ID 102822) requires that additional (plan data scope) requirements be taken into account:For example, for project budget (planning category BUDGET01), plan data scope must NOT be active for WBSElement, FiscalPeriod, FiscalYearPeriod and CompanyCode. For the cost center budget (planning category BUDGET02), plan data scope must NOT be active for FiscalPeriod and FiscalYearPeriod.
  • Balance sheet data as part of financial statement planning requires a balance carry-forward logic to ensure that opening balance and balance sheet movements within a fiscal year are correctly replicated from SAC into table ACDOCP. Like in the SAC Export API, this requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA global field BalanceFlowType (see in below file configuration ID 30001).
  • Costs split into fixed and variable costs in SAC can also be replicated and stored in table ACDOCP, which requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA field FixedVariableType. In this case, the data records split into fixed and variable are merged into one data record on the SAP S/4HANA side, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective “total” measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written into the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).

Example Configurations

Finally, the file in the following URL shows predefined configuration settings to give an idea of how to configure specific content in the mapping and filter section: https://d.dam.sap.com/a/MVuKTRq?rc=10&doi=SAP1225684

The first example (configuration ID 10001) from the file for OPEX-related plan data on cost centers and projects, including value-based allocations, is explained based on screenshots from the manage app:

Mapping of Financial Plan Data

  • For the SAC measure AMOUNT on the SAP S/4HANA side, the measure AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency is used (and the currency derived from a property of the company code), assuming the company code currency in SAC plan data.
  • The displayed plan data scope contains the mandatory plan data scope fields PlanningCategory, CompanyCode and FiscalYearPeriod (or LedgerFiscalYear) and is sufficient if there is no other overlapping configuration ID writing into the same planning category.
  • As described, ProfitCenter and FunctionalArea are not included, as this proposal relies on the derivation rules in SAP S/4HANA to derive the two fields in the background when writing plan data into table ACDOCP.
  • Including the source field FixedVariableType ensures that when writing into table ACDOCP the plan data is reformatted accordingly, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective “total” measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written to the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).
  • In the example, the SAP Planning category PLN is used. Likewise, another category can be selected, which is maintained in SAP S/4HANA with Application Type “Periodic Planning & Consolidation” and Category Usage “NO specific usage” (in SSCUI 101970, Maintain Category for Planning).

Filter Settings for Financial Plan Data

  • The mandatory single value filter for the source field Version is maintained here. In the IFP content, the version Plan is used by default and may need to be adjusted if it differs in the custom data model.
  • It should also be filtered by planning period to select the plan data to the respective planning year.
  • In this example, further filter settings are not necessary because, on the one hand, this configuration is for OPEX-related plan data including cost centers and projects and only the AMOUNT measure is mapped. Other measures are excluded (like measures related to allocation weights ).
